awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Hybrid Incompatibility Genes in Caenorhabditis Species
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project investigates how new biological species form. Laboratory-based efforts to identify genetic and molecular mechanisms of speciation in nematode worms will be aided by the isolation of new worm strains and species by members of the general public. High school students will participate directly in scientific research by collecting nematodes from rotting fruits and flowers. They will learn how research is performed and will also gain a basic understanding of genes, DNA, and evolution that is becoming increasingly more important and societally relevant. By engaging students in the practice of science, this project fulfills one of the three central dimensions in the Next Generation Science Standards recently adopted by many states across the nation and will improve scientific literacy in the general population by helping to build an informed public that understands the scientific enterprise and can better contribute to future national policy decisions that require the interpretation and evaluation of scientific data.

The process of speciation involves the evolution of reproductive barriers between populations within a species so that a single species can split. Though multiple reproductive barriers typically isolate existing species, less is known about which barriers drove the speciation process originally. The goal of the project is to identify genes that cause reproductive isolation and determine their molecular mechanisms of action. The project is focused on identifying genes that mediate incompatibility within species and will operate at three levels to: 1) determine the detailed molecular and cellular mechanism of action of a previously identified intraspecific incompatibility in the nematode C. elegans mediated by a selfish toxin/antidote gene pair, 2) identify the genes involved in a newly discovered nuclear-cytoplasmic intraspecific incompatibility in the related nematode species C. nouraguensis, and 3) systematically search for more intraspecific genetic incompatibilities within the Caenorhabditis genus in a large-scale project to isolate new strains of Caenorhabditis species using a crowdsourcing approach implemented in high school classrooms, and by systematic crosses of strains performed by undergraduate researchers to test for hybrid breakdown.

por.por_cntn:
How new species form is poorly understood. A prevalent idea is that the process of speciation is often initiated by divergent changes in genes in different populations of a species that lead to reduced fitness when members of these populations attempt to reproduce. Accumulation of such genetic incompatibilities could eventually lead to complete reproductive isolation between these populations, hence distinct species. However, this idea has rarely been tested, and few genes that cause incompatibility between species have been discovered. The goal of this project was to identify and characterize the mechanism of genes that cause genetic incompatibility within species and may be important for initiating speciation. In particular, this project focused on genes that cause incompatibility in microscopic worms called nematodes, since these organisms are easily studied in the lab, making them a good model system to study genetic incompatibility.

In one part of the project, the molecular mechanism of a previously identified incompatibility in the nematode C. elegans was studied. This incompatibility is caused by two genes, encoding a protein that acts as a toxin and is transmitted from parents to their progeny via sperm, and a second protein that acts in embryos as an antidote to this toxin. To understand how this toxin kills cells, a genetic screen was performed to identify other proteins necessary for toxicity. A small membrane protein was identified that works with the toxin. Together, these two proteins were sufficient to kill cells not just in worms, but also in insects or in mammalian cells, indicating that no other proteins were needed for toxicity. These toxic proteins cause swelling and bursting of the cell, probably due to disruption of gradients in charged chemicals called ions, leading to excessive water to enter the cell. Further experiments suggest that the two proteins form a channel that allows the improper flow of ions into the cell. This work represents the first molecular understanding of a toxin-antidote systems in animals.

In a second part of the project, a new genetic incompatibility was studied in a different species of nematode worms. This incompatibility is caused by an interaction between two genetic factors: a gene that is encoded on chromosomes in the nucleus as is typical, and an unusual cytoplasmic factor that is transmitted to progeny via the female egg cytoplasm and thus is likely not encoded in the nuclear genome. The project worked towards the identification of these two factors. The genomes of the two incompatible strains were sequenced and the nuclearly-encoded incompatibility genes were mapped to specific chromosomes. One of these genes was mapped to a narrower region of the chromosome and ongoing work is trying to determine the specific gene in this region that contributes to incompatibility. Studies of incompatibility in this species also led to the fortuitous discovery of an unusual type of asexual reproduction when female worms of this species were crossed to male worms of a closely related species. The mechanism was determined by which this cross changed chromosome segregation in these females, causing them to produce an egg with twice the normal number of chromosomes.

The project also had broader impacts in training and education. The project provided training in scientific research for three high school, eight undergraduate, and two graduate students in the lab of the PI. Both graduate students have authored papers published in journals and presented their research at national scientific conferences. Four undergraduate students have also been co-authors on papers. The project also involved hundreds of high school students in a collaborative citizen-science type project to isolate new species of nematode worms from nature, exposing these students to a real world research project, and teaching them how to use DNA sequence information to identify species. Dozens of new strains and species of nematode worms were isolated, including some that were published.
